hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok

hadiths.english_translation: From their own people, known by the kunya Abu al-Hudhayl, and he had heard hadith, and he looked into Islamic jurisprudence, and it overwhelmed him, and was attributed to him, and he died in Basra, and was attributed to Khalid ibn al-Harith, and Abdel-Wahid ibn Ziad. And his father al-Hudhayl was over Ispahan, and his brother Sabah ibn al-Hudhayl was over the charity of Bani Tamim, and Zafar was nothing in hadith.

narrators.name: Zafar ibn al-Hudhayl
narrators.full_name: Zafar ibn al-Hudhayl al-Anbari

chainIssues: Biographical entry without proper hadith transmission

potential_issues.issue: Associated with jurisprudential study rather than hadith

hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Muhammad ibn Sulaym al-Abdi: I heard Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl saying: "My grandfather Ghazwan witnessed the Battle of Qadisiyyah with his master, a man from Bani Dabbah." I asked: What was Ghazwan? He said: A Roman. Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl died in Kufa in the year 195 AH, and Waqi' ibn al-Jarrah witnessed his funeral. He was reliable and truthful, prolific in hadith, and had Shi'ite leanings, though some do not accept him as evidence.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sulaym al-Abdi
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sulaym ibn Daraj al-Abdi

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl ibn Ghazwan al-Dabb

chainIssues: Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl is noted as having Shi'ite leanings (mutashift'an) and some scholars do not accept him as evidence
Incomplete chain for the actual hadith narrative - the grandfather Ghazwan's testimony is being reported through Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl's report

potential_issues.impact: Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl is explicitly noted as having Shi'ite tendencies (متشيعًا), and some scholars reject his testimony as evidence.
The entry combines a narrative about Ghazwan witnessing Qadisiyyah with biographical information about Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl rather than a clear hadith transmission.
While the entry notes he was reliable (ثقة) and truthful (صدوق), it also states 'some do not accept him as evidence' (وبعضهم لا يحتج به), indicating scholarly disagreement.

hadiths.IISGrade: Questionable But Might Be Acceptable
Topics: Incident of ancestor witnessing the Battle of Qadisiyyah

hadiths.english_translation: From Mudhhaj, known by the kunya Abu Muhammad. Talq ibn Ghnam informed us, he said: Abdullah ibn Idris ibn Yazid was born in the year 115 AH during the caliphate of Hisham ibn Abd al-Malik, and he died in Kufa on the tenth of Dhu al-Hijjah in the year 192 AH during the end of the caliphate of Harun. He was reliable, trustworthy, prolific in hadith, an authority, a follower of Sunnah and the community.

hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok

hadiths.english_translation: From Mudhhaj. Talq ibn Ghnam informed us, he said: Hafs ibn Ghiyath was born in the year 117 AH during the caliphate of Hisham ibn Abd al-Malik. He was known by the kunya Abu Umar. Harun, Commander of the Faithful, appointed him as judge in Baghdad on the eastern side, then appointed him as judge of Kufa. He continued as a judge there until he fell ill with a severe illness and died on the tenth of Dhu al-Hijjah in the year 194 AH during the caliphate of Muhammad ibn Harun. He was reliable, trustworthy, established/firm, except that he practiced tadlis.

narrators.name: Talq ibn Ghnam
narrators.full_name: Talq ibn Ghnam ibn Qais

narrators.name: Hafs ibn Ghiyath
narrators.full_name: Hafs ibn Ghiyath ibn Talq ibn Mu'awiyah ibn Malik ibn al-Harith al-Nakhahi

chainIssues: Biographical entry with transmission of biographical information
Subject narrator is noted as practicing tadlis (تدليس)

potential_issues.impact: This entry transmits biographical information about Hafs ibn Ghiyath's birth, death, appointments, and reliability assessment rather than a hadith narrative.

Hafs ibn Ghiyath is explicitly noted as practicing tadlis. While he is considered reliable (thiqah) and established (thabt), the practice of tadlis means his transmissions using ambiguous terms like 'an may introduce uncertainty about direct hearing.

Topics: Biographical information about Hafs ibn Ghiyath

hadiths.english_translation: And the one who attained Islam, and Surd embraced Islam. And Ubaidah's kunya is Abu Muhammad, and his name was Abd al-Rahman, then he was nicknamed Ubaidah which overwhelmed him. And he died in Kufa three days before the end of Rajab in the year 188 AH during the caliphate of Harun. Muhammad ibn Rabi'ah al-Kalabi prayed the funeral prayer over him, and he was reliable.
